translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in the Eastern Park, in the Palace of Migāra’s Mother. 🔽Then, when it was evening, the venerable Ānanda rose from meditation and went to the Blessed One.

original: ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: After paying homage to the Blessed One, he sat down at one side and said to him:

analyzed: ekam idam bhante samayam bhagavā sakkesu viharati nagarakam nāma sakyānam nigamaḥ
translated: “Venerable sir, on one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling among the Sakyans, where there is a town of the Sakyans named Nagaraka.

original: Tattha me, bhante, bhagavato sammukhā sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
analyzed: tattha me bhante bhagavato sammukhā suta sammukhā paṭiggahita
translated: There the Blessed One spoke thus:

original: ‘suññatāvihārenāhaṁ, ānanda, etarahi bahulaṁ viharāmī’ti.
analyzed: suñña tā vihārena āha ānanda etarahi bahulam viharāmi iti
translated: ‘Ānanda, I often dwell in voidness.’

original: Kacci metaṁ, bhante, sussutaṁ suggahitaṁ sumanasikataṁ sūpadhāritan”ti?
analyzed: kacci mā ita bhante sussutam suggahitam su manasikatam su upadhāritam ti
translated: Have I understood the Dhamma correctly?”

original: “Taggha te etaṁ, ānanda, sussutaṁ suggahitaṁ sumanasikataṁ sūpadhāritaṁ.
analyzed: tat ha te ete ānanda su sutam suggahitam su manasikatam su upadhārita
translated: “Certainly, Ānanda, you have understood the Dhamma correctly in that you have learned it well, retained it well, and mastered it well.

original: Pubbepāhaṁ, ānanda, etarahipi suññatāvihārena bahulaṁ viharāmi.
analyzed: pubbepāha ānanda etarahipi suñña tā vihārena bahulam viharāmi
translated: In the past, Ānanda, and also now, I usually stay with a mind-made seclusion.

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, ayaṁ migāramātupāsādo suñño hatthigavassavaḷavena, suñño jātarūparajatena, suñño itthipurisasannipātena atthi cevidaṁ asuññataṁ yadidaṁ—

translated: Just as this Migāramātā’s Monastry is empty of elephants, cows, horses, and mares, empty of gold and silver, empty of women and men, but there is this non-emptiness here, namely—

original: Tassa araññasaññāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.

translated: ‘Whatever disturbances there might be dependent on the perception of village, those are not present here; whatever disturbances there might be dependent on the perception of people, those are not present here. There is present only this amount of disturbance, namely—

translated: He understands: ‘This field of perception is void of the perception of village, this field of perception is void of the perception of human beings.

original: araññasaññaṁ paṭicca ekattan’ti.

translated: There is present only this non-voidness, namely, the singleness dependent on the perception of forest.’

original: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṁ suññaṁ samanupassati, yaṁ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṁ hoti taṁ ‘santamidaṁ atthī’ti pajānāti.

translated: This, Ānanda, is the way in which there is the entering upon and dwelling in voidness that is based upon a distinction.

original: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā manussasaññaṁ, amanasikaritvā araññasaññaṁ, pathavīsaññaṁ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṁ.

translated: “Again, Ananda, a bhikkhu, not attending to the perception of the base of infinite consciousness, not attending to the perception of the base of nothingness, attends to the singleness dependent on the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Tassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
analyzed: tassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatana saññāya cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati
translated: As he attends thus, his mind enters into that perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and acquires confidence, steadiness, and decision.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti
translated: He understands thus:

original: ‘ye assu darathā viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṁ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṁ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṁ darathamattā yadidaṁ—
analyzed: ye assu darathāḥ viññāṇañca āyatana saññam paṭicca te idha na santi ye assu darathāḥ ākiñcaññāyatana saññam paṭicca te idha na santi atthi ca iva ayam daratha mattā yat idam
translated: ‘Whatever disturbances there might be dependent on the perception of the base of infinite consciousness, those are not present here; whatever disturbances there might be dependent on the perception of the base of nothingness, those are not present here. There is present only this amount of disturbance, namely,

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṁ paṭicca ekattan’ti.
analyzed: nevasaññā anāsañña āyatana saññam paṭicca ekattam ti
translated: the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and the singleness dependent on that.’

original: So ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ viññāṇañcāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ ākiñcaññāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṁ asuññataṁ yadidaṁ—🔽nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṁ paṭicca ekattan’ti.
analyzed: so suññam idam saññā āgatam viññāṇaṃ ca āyatana saññāya ati pajānāti suññam idam saññā āgatam ākiñcañña āyatana saññāya ati pajānāti atthi ceva idam a suññatam yat idam  nevasaññā anāsañña āyatana saññam paṭicca ekattam ti
translated: He understands: ‘This field of perception is void of the perception of the base of infinite consciousness. This field of perception is void of the perception of the base of nothingness. But there is present only this non-voidness, namely, the singleness dependent on the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.’

original: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṁ suññaṁ samanupassati, yaṁ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṁ hoti taṁ ‘santamidaṁ atthī’ti pajānāti.🔽Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
analyzed: iti yat hi kho tattha na hoti tena tam suññam samanupassati yam pana tattha avasiṭṭham hoti tam santam idam atthi iti pajānāti  evam pissa esā ānanda yathābhuccā a vipallatthā parisuddhā suñña tā avakkanti bhavati
translated: Thus, in regard to this he abides contemplating non-existence as non-existence.

original: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṁ, amanasikaritvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṁ, animittaṁ cetosamādhiṁ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṁ.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ ānanda bhikkhu a manasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatana sañña a manasikaritvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatana sañña animittam cetaḥ samādhim paṭicca manasi karoti ekatta
translated: “Again, Ananda, a bhikkhu, not attending to the perception of the base of nothingness, not attending to the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, attends to the singleness dependent on the signless concentration of mind.

original: Tassa animitte cetosamādhimhi cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
analyzed: tassa animitte cetosamādhimhi cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati
translated: His mind enters into that signless concentration of mind and acquires confidence, steadiness, and decision.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti
translated: He understands thus:

original: ‘ye assu darathā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṁ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṁ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṁ darathamattā yadidaṁ—
analyzed: ye assu darathāḥ ākiñcañña āyatana saññam paṭicca te idha na santi ye assu darathāḥ nevasaññānāsaññāyatana saññam paṭicca te idha na santi atthi ca iva ayam daratha mattā yat idam
translated: ‘Whatever disturbances there are that are dependent on the perception of the base of nothingness, they are not present here. Whatever disturbances there are that are dependent on the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, they are not present here. But this much of disturbance remains, namely,

original: imameva kāyaṁ paṭicca saḷāyatanikaṁ jīvitapaccayā’ti.
analyzed: imam eva kāyam paṭicca saḷāyatanikam jīvita paccayā ti
translated: this body with its six bases for contact and the life that is dependent on conditions.’

original: So ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ ākiñcaññāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṁ asuññataṁ yadidaṁ—
analyzed: so suññam idam saññāgatam ākiñcañña āyatana saññāya ati pajānāti suññam idam saññāgatam nevasaññānāsaññāyatana saññāya ati pajānāti atthi ceva idam a suññatam yat idam
translated: He understands: ‘This field of perception is void of the perception of the base of nothingness. This field of perception is void of the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. But this is present, namely,

original: imameva kāyaṁ paṭicca saḷāyatanikaṁ jīvitapaccayā’ti.
analyzed: imam eva kāyam paṭicca saḷāyatanikam jīvita paccayā ti
translated: this body with its six bases for contact and the life that is dependent on conditions.’

original: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṁ suññaṁ samanupassati, yaṁ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṁ hoti taṁ ‘santamidaṁ atthī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: iti yat hi kho tattha na hoti tena tam suññam samanupassati yam pana tattha avasiṭṭham hoti tam santam idam atthi iti pajānāti
translated: So he regards it as void of whatever is not there. But as to what remains there, he understands that which is present thus: ‘This is present.’

original: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
analyzed: evam pissa esā ānanda yathābhuccā a vipallatthā parisuddhā suñña tā avakkanti bhavati
translated: In this way, Ananda, his entry into voidness is in conformity with what is factual, not contrary to it, purified, transcending the world of formations.

original: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṁ, amanasikaritvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṁ, animittaṁ cetosamādhiṁ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṁ.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ ānanda bhikkhu a manasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatana sañña a manasikaritvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatana sañña animittam cetaḥ samādhim paṭicca manasi karoti ekatta
translated: “Again, Ānanda, a bhikkhu, not attending to the perception of the base of nothingness, not attending to the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, attends to the singleness dependent on the signless concentration of mind.

original: Tassa animitte cetosamādhimhi cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
analyzed: tassa animitte cetosamādhimhi cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati
translated: His mind enters into that signless concentration of mind and acquires confidence, steadiness, and decision.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti
translated: He understands thus:

original: ‘ayampi kho animitto cetosamādhi abhisaṅkhato abhisañcetayito’.
analyzed: ayam pi kho animittaḥ cetaḥ samādhi abhisaṅkhataḥ abhisañcetayito
translated: ‘This signless concentration of mind is conditioned and volitionally produced.

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: Whatever is conditioned and volitionally produced is impermanent, subject to cessation.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: Vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti
translated: He understands thus:

original: ‘ye assu darathā kāmāsavaṁ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā bhavāsavaṁ paṭicca
analyzed: ye assu darathā kāma āsavam paṭicca te idha na santi ye assu darathā bhava āsavam paṭicca
translated: ‘Whatever distress there is dependent on the taint of sensual desire is absent here,

original: tedha na santi, ye assu darathā avijjāsavaṁ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṁ🔽darathamattā yadidaṁ—🔽imameva kāyaṁ paṭicca saḷāyatanikaṁ jīvitapaccayā’ti.
analyzed: tedha na santi ye assu darathāḥ a vijja āsavam paṭicca tedha na santi atthi cevāya  daratha mattā  imam eva kāyam paṭicca saḷāyatanikam jīvita paccayā ti
translated: whatever distress there is dependent on the taint of being is absent here,🔽whatever distress there is dependent on the taint of ignorance is absent here. But there is this distress that is dependent on this body, which is made up of the four great elements and supported by food.

original: So ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ kāmāsavenā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ bhavāsavenā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṁ saññāgataṁ avijjāsavenā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṁ asuññataṁ yadidaṁ—
analyzed: so suññam idam saññāgatam kāma āsavena ati pajānāti suññam idam saññāgatam bhava āsavena ati pajānāti suññam idam saññāgatam avijjā āsavena ati pajānāti atthi ceva idam a suññatam yat idam
translated: He understands: ‘This field of perception is void of the taint of sensual desire. This field of perception is void of the taint of being. This field of perception is void of the taint of ignorance. But there is this that is not void, namely,

original: imameva kāyaṁ paṭicca saḷāyatanikaṁ jīvitapaccayā’ti.
analyzed: imam eva kāyam paṭicca saḷāyatanikam jīvita paccayā ti
translated: this body, which is made up of the four great elements and supported by food.’

original: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṁ suññaṁ samanupassati, yaṁ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṁ hoti taṁ ‘santamidaṁ atthī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: iti yat hi kho tattha na hoti tena tam suññam samanupassati yam pana tattha avasiṭṭham hoti tam santam idam atthi iti pajānāti
translated: So he regards it as void of what is not there, and as to what remains there he understands: ‘There is this.’

original: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā paramānuttarā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.🔽Yepi hi keci, ānanda, atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ
analyzed: evam pissa esā ānanda yathābhuccā a vipallatthā parisuddhā paramā anuttarā suññatā avakkanti bhavati  ye api hi keci ānanda atīta maddhānam samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā parisuddham parama anuttara
translated: And so, Ananda, this is the purification by knowledge and vision of the way, the unsurpassed method of purification by knowledge and vision of the way that leads to the complete destruction of suffering.

original: suññataṁ upasampajja vihariṁsu, sabbe te imaṁyeva parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ suññataṁ🔽upasampajja vihariṁsu.🔽Yepi hi keci, ānanda, anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ
analyzed: suññatam upasampajja viharisu sabbe te imayā iva parisuddham parama anuttaram suññata  upasampajja viharisu  ye api hi keci ānanda anāgata maddhānam samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā parisuddham parama anuttara
translated: “Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the past have purified their knowledge and vision of the way, all of them have purified it in this way.

original: suññataṁ upasampajja viharissanti, sabbe te imaṁyeva parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ suññataṁ🔽upasampajja viharissanti.🔽Yepi hi keci, ānanda, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ suññataṁ
analyzed: suññatam upasampajja viharissanti sabbe te imayā iva parisuddham parama anuttaram suññata  upasampajja viharissanti  ye api hi keci ānanda etarahi samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā parisuddham parama anuttaram
translated: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the future will purify their knowledge and vision of the way, all of them will purify it in this way.

original: upasampajja viharanti, sabbe te imaṁyeva parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ suññataṁ upasampajja viharanti.
analyzed: upasampajja viharanti sabbe te imayā iva parisuddham parama anuttaram suññatam upasampajja viharanti
translated: Whatever ascetics and brahmins at present purify their knowledge and vision of the way, all of them purify it in this way.🔽“This, Ananda, is the unsurpassed teaching of the Dhamma in which one who has entered upon it rightly goes to the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Tasmātiha, ānanda, ‘parisuddhaṁ paramānuttaraṁ suññataṁ upasampajja viharissāmā’ti—
analyzed: tasmā ati ha ānanda parisuddham parama anuttaram suññatam upasampajja viharissāma ati
translated: Therefore, Ānanda, you should train the mind like this: ‘We will enter & remain in that supreme release that is void.’

original: evañhi vo, ānanda, sikkhitabban”ti.
analyzed: evam hi vaḥ ānanda sikkhitabbanti
translated: That’s how you should train the mind.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.🔽Cūḷasuññatasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ paṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi iti 🔽cūḷasuññata suttam niṭṭhitam paṭhama
translated: Pleased, the venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Blessed One said.🔽The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness is finished.
